subject: Classpath troubleshooting JUnit 3.8.1, Redhat 9, JDK 1.4.1_02/01
msgSnippet: I installed Redhat 9, junit 3.8.1, and two JDK s -- 1.4.1 versions 01 and 02. Regardless of how I set classpath, the TestRunner will run and find no classes.

I installed Redhat 9, junit 3.8.1, and two JDK's -- 1.4.1 versions 01
and 02.

Regardless of how I set classpath, the TestRunner will run and
find no classes.  

It is puzzling that junit.jar can be found in order to run the
TestRunner class, but it cannot find the junit.samples.AllTests
class.

A few specific questions:
1) I have tried copying junit.jar to various locations.  It
starts out in the junit3.8.1 directory.  Is the standard procedure
to use that directory as its home, or is it normally moved to the
JDK lib directory.  Would this make any difference?

2) On Redhat 8.0, the swingui TestRunner could find and run
tests on some built-in classes, such as junit.samples.money.MoneyTest.
Now with Redhat 9, a clean install with no files from the old 
system, no test classes can be found -- not VectorTest, not 
money.MoneyTest, not samples.AllTests, nor tests.AllTests.  Does
anyone know why these were found in Redhat 8 but not Redhat 9?

3) Is there any kind of minimum hardware requirement?  I haven't
seen one in the documentation, but I'm running this on a bad
machine, namely a 300 MHz x86 with 256 MB RAM.

4) The documentation for the installation process gives exactly
one troubleshooting tip.  It advises that if the initial tests do
not run, one should check to make sure that the junit.jar is on
the classpath.  If one is certain that junit.jar IS on the classpath
but it's still not working, one seems to be out of luck.  Are there
any other JUnit troubleshooting documents or sources?

5) Dave Astels posted earlier that he is using Redhat 9, Java 1.4.1
01, and junit 3.8.1.  Are there other Linux JUnit users who can 
compare their configurations, and possibly post configuration files 
such as .bashrc, etc.?  

Thanks
